awd_titl_txt: Functional dissection of cerebellar circuits for emotional learning and memory
awd_abstract_narration:
When conditions around organisms change in a way that violates their expectations, this change drives learning and the formation of new memories. How the brain detects the violation of expectations and processes it to support learning and memory is unclear but is thought to involve several brain regions, prominent among which is the cerebellum. The cerebellum is known to regulate learning of fine movements and motor coordination, and its role in non-motor functions is only now beginning to be appreciated. The investigators in this project will determine the contribution of the cerebellum to emotional learning and memory. Specifically, the investigators are examining whether communication between the cerebellum and emotion-regulating brain circuits is necessary during learning and/or recollection of threat-related emotional memories. By using novel technologies, the investigators selectively and reversibly interfere with this communication in a spatially and temporally precise manner and can thus determine its functional significance. The knowledge gained from this investigation will inform understanding of cerebellar function and of the neurobiology of emotion, with implications for neurodevelopmental and post-traumatic stress disorders. The investigators also capitalize on the fact that formation of emotional memories is a fascinating topic to which people with diverse backgrounds can readily relate and are i) mentoring undergraduate students from groups underrepresented in STEM in laboratory research; ii) continuing and expanding a public outreach initiative, which brings the latest brain science achievements to the general public and engages UC Davis trainees in public speaking to non-specialists; iii) disseminating information about brain science and research career choices to Hispanic communities locally and world-wide; and iv) are developing workshops for K-12 educators, to help further their science background and recommend ways to incorporate brain science in educational curricula.

There is growing appreciation for the modulatory role of the cerebellum in social and affective behaviors, in addition to its established role in motor control. However, the mechanistic link between the cerebellum and emotional learning and memory is lacking. Functional connections exist between the cerebellum and the amygdala, raising the exciting possibility that a cerebello-amygdala circuit processes information important for emotional learning and memory. The overarching objective of this proposal is to understand the role of the functional connectivity between the cerebellum and amygdala-based emotional circuits in learned emotion.  The investigators hypothesize that the cerebellum causally contributes to threat-related emotional learning and memory through projections to emotional circuits. They are testing this hypothesis at the microcircuit and synaptic levels through a multifaceted approach, which leverages the spatiotemporal resolution of optogenetic and pharmacogenetic tools to dissociate motor from non-motor effects. The expectation is that if communication between the cerebellum and specific emotional centers is necessary for learned emotion, then inhibition of cerebellar projections should impair aspects of learned emotion. The project is conceptually innovative because it assigns for the first time emotional functionality to cerebellar projections that are well-conserved across mammals but have received little attention to-date. It is also technically innovative because it employs for the first time an approach to the study of the cerebellum and learned emotion that minimizes compensatory effects and enables the separation of motor from non-motor contributions. The potential exists to break new ground in the understanding of cerebellar function and of the neurobiology of emotion. Finally, the project is of broad interest as it offers deep insights into principles of motivated behavior and sheds light into the role of traditionally-considered motor areas in non-motor functions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit

Widely accepted as a control center for movement coordination and motor learning, the cerebellum has emerged as a regulator of emotional learning and memory in both animals and humans and has been implicated in affective disorders. How does the cerebellum serve emotional learning and memory? The answer to this question remains unclear but could conceivably involve timing of learned responses, generation of predictions important for learning and assignment of incentive salience, and/or storage of affective memories. To test these possibilities, knowledge of the circuitry that connects the cerebellum to emotion centers is imperative, and so is the ability to precisely manipulate this circuitry in vivo. Short- and long-latency responses have been described in the amygdala -a structure central for processing emotion and attributing valence to stimuli - upon cerebellar stimulation. This observation raised the exciting possibility that a cerebello-amygdala circuit computes information important for emotional learning and memory. The goal of our project was 1) to identify neural circuitry underlying cerebello-amygdala connectivity; and 2) to manipulate this circuitry in a temporally and spatially precise manner so as to identify causal relationships between neural circuit elements and affective behavior.

Towards the first goal, we hypothesized that the short-latency responses between cerebellum and amygdala are supported by a disynaptic anatomical circuit. We launched a series of anatomical and electrophysiological studies, which uncovered a disynaptic pathway between the deep cerebellar output nuclei and the basolateral amygdala through the intralaminar thalamus including the centromedial and parafasicular (CM and PF) nuclei. These studies were recently published (Jung, Vlasov et al. Front. Syst. Neurosci, 2022) and provided the first systematic characterization of cerebello-amygdala connectivity.

Toward the second goal, we hypothesized that this connectivity causally contributes to emotional learning and memory. Using reversible and spatiotemporally precise inhibition of neural activity during emotional learning and memory, we found that cerebello-thalamic connections regulate the rate of fear extinction without affecting fear acquisition itself. This effect was not due to impaired motor performance or altered anxiety-related internal emotional state. Our interpretation of these findings is that the cerebellum processes signals about prediction, which it communicates through a cerebello-thalamic pathway to the amygdala to modulate incentive salience and processing of learned fear. Our study provided the first evidence of a causal role for a novel cerebellar pathway in fear extinction learning. Our findings have been published in the form of abstracts (Vlasov et al., #639.11. 2022 Neuroscience Meeting Planner. San Diego; Jung et al., #P276.04. Society for Neuroscience Global Connectome. 2021), which have been presented at international meetings and are part of a manuscript under preparation. Overall, our findings advance our understanding for how the cerebellum can modulate complex cognitive and limbic functions and aim to guide future studies of how these circuits may be impaired in neuropsychiatric disorders.

 

Broader impacts

How the brain controls emotions is a fascinating question that captures the interest of people from diverse backgrounds. Capitalizing on this interest, we designed a comprehensive project that seamlessly integrated our research and educational missions and promoted enthusiasm about brain science, scientific literacy and inquisitive thinking.  Our outreach program was impacted by Covid-19-related restrictions, which were in place during 2020-2021. Nonetheless, we still managed to deliver on three of the four proposed aims. Specifically, our project encompassed:

1) Training of undergraduate students in the laboratory setting of the Principle Investigator (PI), with an emphasis on students from underrepresented minority groups: during the lifetime of the award, nineteen undergraduate students were trained in the PI?s laboratory, eight of whom self-identified as members of underserved, underprivileged groups.

2) Active participation of the PI?s trainees as well as of UC Davis neuroscience program students and postdocs in public outreach efforts spearheaded by the PI: during the award period, we organized and participated in visits to inner city schools in the broader Sacramento area.

3) Dissemination of information about brain science and research careers to underserved communities. Aiming at educating the community on the significance and the latest advancements of brain research, we organized NeuroFest, an annual celebration of brain science, which includes public lectures, poster presentations by trainees, interactive educational booths, and info-booths that aim to increase support for STEM research and to recruit the next generation of neuroscientists. Bilingual advertising of the event targeted Hispanic populations. Talks were recorded and uploaded on the internet, enabling us to reach a far broader audience.
